questions.text: Which of the following structures develops from the structure marked?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Median umbilical ligament

Explanation:

  • The marked structure is the allantois, a hindgut diverticulum. It forms the urachus during fetal development, connecting the bladder apex to the umbilicus, which later degenerates into the median umbilical ligament. This ligament runs along the midline of abdominal wall.

 

Fetal Structure

Postnatal derivative

Notes

Ductus arteriosus

Ligamentum arteriosum

Near the left recurrent laryngeal nerve

Ductus venosus

Ligamentum venosum

-

Foramen ovale

Fossa ovalis

-

Allantois → urachus

Median umbilical ligament

Urachus is part of allantois between bladder and umbilicus

Umbilical arteries

Medial umbilical ligaments

(Option A)

-

Umbilical vein

Ligamentum teres hepatis (round ligament)

(Option D)

Contained in falciform ligament

Meckel's diverticulum (Option C): This arises from the vitelline duct, not the urachus.

questions.text: A child lacks thymus and inferior parathyroid glands. Defective development of which of the following structures is likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) 3

 

Explanation:

The thymus and inferior parathyroid glands are both derived from the third pharyngeal pouch.

  • Thymus: Forms from the endoderm of the third pharyngeal pouch, and is responsible for the development of T lymphocytes.
  • Inferior parathyroid glands: Also arise from the third pharyngeal pouch, and are responsible for calcium homeostasis through parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion.

If there is a defect in the development of the third pharyngeal pouch, both the thymus and inferior parathyroid glands would fail to develop, leading to conditions such as DiGeorge syndrome, which is characterized by thymic hypoplasia and hypoparathyroidism.

 

Pharyngeal arches, clefts and pouches

Pharyngeal arches
  • Pharyngeal arches are key structures in head and neck development, appearing in the fourth and fifth weeks as mesenchymal tissue bars.
  • They resemble gills but do not function as such in humans.
  • Pharyngeal arches are divided by pharyngeal clefts on the outside and pharyngeal pouches on the inside.
  • Pharyngeal pouches develop as outpocketings from the lateral walls of the pharynx and do not connect to the exterior, playing crucial roles in organ development.
  • Each arch incorporates neural crest cells essential for forming facial skeleton components, while mesoderm differentiates into facial and neck musculature.
  • Each arch has its own cranial nerve and artery.

Pharyngeal Pouches
  • Four Pairs (fifth is rudimentary)
  • First Pouch: Forms the middle ear cavity and Eustachian tube, contributing to the tympanic membrane.
  • Second Pouch: Develops into palatine tonsils; remnants persist as the tonsillar fossa.
  • Third Pouch: Dorsal wing becomes the inferior parathyroid gland; ventral wing forms the thymus, migrating to the thorax.
  • Fourth Pouch: Dorsal region forms the superior parathyroid gland; ventral region becomes the ultimobranchial body, integrating into the thyroid.

Pharyngeal Clefts
  • Five-week-old Embryo: Four clefts are present.
  • First Cleft: Does not form the external auditory meatus (EAM); instead, the EAM arises from surface ectoderm invagination. It eventually disappears due to overgrowth by the second arch.
  • Second, Third, and Fourth Clefts: Overgrown by the second arch, they lose exterior contact and may temporarily form the cervical sinus, which ultimately disappears.



First pharyngeal pouch (Option A) is incorrect because it gives rise to the auditory tube and middle ear cavity, not the thymus or parathyroid glands.


Second pharyngeal pouch (Option B) is incorrect because it forms the palatine tonsils, not the thymus or parathyroid glands.


Fourth pharyngeal pouch (Option D) is incorrect because it gives rise to the superior parathyroid glands and parts of the ultimobranchial body, not the thymus or inferior parathyroid glands.

questions.text: A newborn presented to the NICU with respiratory distress and meconium discharge from the umbilicus. The condition occurs due to the patency of which structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vitelline Fistula

Explanation:

  • A vitelline fistula occurs due to the failure of the vitelline duct (omphalomesenteric duct) to obliterate, leading to meconium discharge from the umbilicus. It connects the midgut to the yolk sac during fetal development, and its persistence results in fecal or intestinal content drainage from the umbilicus.

Embryological Remnants of Umbilical Structures

Structure

Embryological Origin

Failure of Obliteration Leads to

Clinical Presentation

Vitelline Duct

Connects midgut to yolk sac

Vitelline fistula

Meconium discharge from the umbilicus

Urachus

Remnant of allantois (connects bladder to umbilicus)

Patent urachus

Urine discharge from umbilicus

Allantois

Contributes to bladder development

Urachal cyst, urachal sinus

Cystic swelling or umbilical urine leakage

Mesonephric Duct

Wolffian duct (forms male reproductive structures)

No relation to umbilical anomalies

Affects male genital development

 

Mesonephric duct (Option A): Incorrect because it forms the male reproductive system (vas deferens, epididymis, seminal vesicles) and does not contribute to umbilical structures.

Allantois (Option B): Incorrect because it contributes to bladder development, and its failure results in urachal anomalies (urine leakage, not meconium discharge).

Urachus (Option C): Incorrect because a patent urachus leads to urinary discharge from the umbilicus, not meconium.

questions.text: What is the embryological basis of the developmental defects shown in the image below?

choices.text: Failure in closure of anterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of posterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of complete neural tube
Failure in closure of caudal neuropore of neural tube

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Failure in closure of anterior neuropore of neural tube

Explanation:

  • The left image shows anencephaly, a severe neural tube defect (NTD) caused by failure of the anterior neuropore to close during embryogenesis (by day 25 of gestation). This leads to absence of the brain, skull, and scalp, with exposed brain tissue. The right image suggests difficulty in feeding, which is often associated with cranial NTDs.

Neural Tube Defects (NTDs) and Neuropore Closure Defects

Neuropore

Failure of Closure Leads to

Clinical Features

Anterior Neuropore

Anencephaly

Absence of brain, skull, and scalp; open cranial vault; polyhydramnios (due to absent swallowing reflex)

Posterior Neuropore

Spina bifida (Occulta, Meningocele, Myelomeningocele)

Defects in vertebral arch, meninges, or spinal cord; may present with tuft of hair, sac-like protrusion, or neurological deficits

Complete Neural Tube

Craniorachischisis

Entire brain and spinal cord remain open, leading to lethal defects

Caudal Neuropore

Spina bifida occulta

Mildest form of spina bifida, often asymptomatic, with a tuft of hair over the lumbar region

 

Failure in closure of posterior neuropore (Option B): Incorrect because it causes spina bifida, affecting the spinal cord and vertebral column, not the brain.

Failure in closure of the complete neural tube (Option C): Incorrect because it results in craniorachischisis, a lethal defect where both the brain and spinal cord remain open.

Failure in closure of caudal neuropore (Option D): Incorrect because it leads to spina bifida occulta, a mild defect limited to the lower spine, not affecting brain development.

questions.text: A young child with absent thymus is brought to the OPD with features of hypoparathyroidism and tetany. Which of the following marked areas in the picture is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image represents the development of pharyngeal pouches. The condition described is DiGeorge syndrome, which is caused by defective development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches, leading to:

  • Absence of thymus → Immunodeficiency (T-cell deficiency)

  • Hypoparathyroidism → Hypocalcemia and tetany

The 3rd pharyngeal pouch (marked as 3) gives rise to:

  • Thymus

  • Inferior parathyroid glands

The 4th pharyngeal pouch gives rise to:

  • Superior parathyroid glands

  • Ultimobranchial body (C-cells of thyroid)

Since DiGeorge syndrome mainly affects the 3rd pouch, the correct answer is Option C (3).

Pharyngeal Pouch Derivatives

Pharyngeal Pouch

Derivatives

1st Pouch

Eustachian tube (Auditory tube)

Middle ear cavity

Mastoid air cells

2nd Pouch

Palatine tonsil (epithelial crypts)

Tonsillar fossa

3rd Pouch

Inferior parathyroid glands

Thymus

4th Pouch

Superior parathyroid glands

Ultimobranchial body (forms C-cells of the thyroid)

DiGeorge Syndrome:

  • Cause: Deletion of 22q11.2, leading to defective neural crest migration

  • CATCH-22

    • Cardiac defects (Tetralogy of Fallot, truncus arteriosus)

    • Abnormal face

    • Thymic aplasia (T-cell immunodeficiency)

    • Cleft palate

    • Hypocalcemia (due to parathyroid agenesis)

    • 22q11.2 deletion

1- (Option A): Incorrect, as the 1st pouch develops into the Eustachian tube and middle ear cavity, unrelated to the thymus or parathyroid.

2- (Option B): Incorrect, as the 2nd pouch forms the palatine tonsils, not affected in DiGeorge syndrome.

4-(Option D): Incorrect, as while the 4th pouch forms the superior parathyroid glands, the major defect in DiGeorge syndrome is due to failure of 3rd pouch development.

questions.text: The marked structure develops from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Supracardinal vein

Explanation:

The marked structure is the azygos vein, which develops primarily from the right supracardinal vein during embryogenesis.

  • The supracardinal veins appear in the embryo as part of the venous system and contribute to the formation of azygos and hemiazygos veins.
  • The right supracardinal vein persists to form the azygos vein, which drains blood from the posterior thoracic wall.
  • The left supracardinal vein contributes to the hemiazygos vein, which drains into the azygos system.

Thus, the correct answer is Option C (Supracardinal vein).

Venous System Development

Embryonic Vein

Adult Derivative

Common cardinal vein

Contributes to superior vena cava (SVC)

Anterior cardinal vein

Forms jugular veins and part of SVC

Supracardinal vein

Azygos and hemiazygos veins

Subcardinal vein

Renal veins, gonadal veins, and part of IVC

 

Common cardinal vein (Option A): Incorrect – Contributes to the formation of the superior vena cava (SVC) but not the azygos vein.

Anterior cardinal vein (Option B): Incorrect – Develops into internal jugular veins and part of the SVC, not the azygos system.

Subcardinal vein (Option D): Incorrect – Primarily forms renal veins and parts of the inferior vena cava (IVC), not the azygos vein.

questions.text: What structure develops from the region labeled as "A" in the model of embryological heart development?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Infundibulum

Explanation:

  • In the embryological development of the heart, the area marked as "A" corresponds to the outflow tract of the developing heart. This outflow tract gives rise to several structures, including the infundibulum. The infundibulum is a conical structure located at the outflow of the right ventricle. It connects the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery and directs blood flow from the heart to the lungs.

Formation of Heart Tubes:

  • The endothelial heart tube is derived from the splanchnopleuric mesoderm, located near the pericardial cavity.
  • Initially, the heart appears as right and left endothelial heart tubes.
  • These tubes fuse to form a single heart tube.
  • The heart tube has 5 dilatations, which are:
    • Truncus arteriosus
    • Bulbus cordis
    • Primitive ventricle
    • Primitive atrium
    • Sinus venosus
  • Sinus venosus is located at the caudal (venous) end of the primitive heart tube.
    • It consists of a body with two prolongations known as the right and left horns.
    • Right horn: Forms smooth part of the right atrium (sinus venarum).
    • Left horn: Forms coronary sinus.
    • Each horn receives blood from three veins:
      • Vitelline vein
      • Umbilical vein
      • Common cardinal vein
  • Bulbus cordis is the cranial most part of the developing heart tube.
    • Forms outflow (smooth) parts of the right ventricle (conus arteriosus) and left ventricle (aortic vestibule).
  • Primitive ventricle: Forms inflow (rough) parts of both ventricles.
  • Primitive atrium: Forms trabeculated part of the right and left atrium.
  • Truncus arteriosus: Forms ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk.

Formation of Transverse Pericardial Sinus:

  • Heart Tube Folding: Brings the arterial and venous ends closer together.
  • Disappearance of the dorsal mesocardium creates the transverse sinus of the pericardium.
  • Parietal and visceral layers of the serous pericardium become continuous at the arterial and venous ends of the heart.
  • Pericardium forms two tubes:
    • One enclosing the aorta and pulmonary trunk.
    • Other enclosing the SVC, IVC, and four pulmonary veins.
  • Two tubes are separated by the transverse sinus of the pericardium.

Atria (Option A): The atria develop from the primitive heart tube, specifically from the regions known as the primitive atrium and sinus venosus.

Left ventricle (Option B): The left ventricle develops from the primitive heart tube and forms the main pumping chamber of the heart that sends oxygenated blood to the systemic circulation.

Interventricular septum (Option D): The interventricular septum develops from the fusion of several components during heart development.

questions.text: The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of which arch artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D) 6th arch

Explanation:

  • The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the aortic arch, which is derived from the sixth aortic arch. During embryonic development, the sixth arch contributes to the formation of the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus, and the recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the aortic arch on the left side, giving it its characteristic long course.

 

Recurrent laryngeal nerve anatomy:

  • The right recurrent laryngeal nerve branches from the vagus at the level of the subclavian artery, looping around it before ascending between the trachea and esophagus.
  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve arises at the arch of the aorta, loops around it, and ascends along the tracheoesophageal groove, giving it a longer course compared to the right nerve, making it more prone to injury.

 

Superior laryngeal nerve:

  • Origin - from the inferior ganglion of the vagus nerve; courses behind the internal carotid artery; divides into external and internal branches at the level of the greater cornua of the hyoid bone.
  • The external branch innervates the cricothyroid muscle.
  • The internal branch provides sensory innervation to the larynx and hypopharynx after piercing through the thyrohyoid membrane.

 

3rd arch (Option A): This is incorrect because the 3rd arch gives rise to the common carotid artery and part of the internal carotid artery, but not the structures associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

4th arch (Option B): This is incorrect for the left recurrent laryngeal nerve, as the right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the right subclavian artery, which is derived from the 4th arch. The left recurrent nerve loops around the aortic arch, which is from the sixth arch.

5th arch (Option C): This is incorrect because the 5th arch is rudimentary and does not contribute to the development of significant vascular structures or nerves.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding anatomical closure is incorrect?

choices.text: Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days
Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 2 to 3 weeks
Right umbilical vein is absent after birth
Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks

questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days

Explanation:

  • Foramen ovale does not anatomically close within 3 to 5 days. Functional closure occurs soon after birth due to increased left atrial pressure, but anatomical closure (fusion of the septum primum and septum secundum) takes months to years. In some individuals, it may persist as a patent foramen ovale (PFO).
  • Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 2 to 3 weeks (option B): The ductus venosus shunts oxygenated blood from the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava in fetal circulation. After birth, it functionally closes within hours and anatomically closes in 2 to 3 weeks, forming the ligamentum venosum.

 

 

Formation of the Interatrial Septum:

Septum Primum

 
  • Formed as a sickle-shaped fold from the roof and dorsal wall of the primitive atrium due to pressure from the bulbus cordis.
  • Grows downward toward the atrioventricular (AV) canal and septum intermedium, fusing with the latter.

Ostium Primum

 

Before the septum primum reaches and fuses with the septum intermedium, a gap (foramen primum) allows blood flow between the right and left atria.

Ostium Secundum

Upper part of the septum primum breaks down, creating a new gap (foramen secundum) before the foramen primum closes. The septum primum now has a free upper edge.

Septum Secundum

Grows down from the roof of the atrial chamber, to the right of the septum primum, overlapping the free upper edge of the septum primum as it grows.

Foramen Ovale Formation
  • Overlapping septa create the foramen ovale, allowing blood to flow from right to left atrium during fetal life, preventing left-to-right flow.
  • Patent throughout fetal life.

Obliteration of Foramen Ovale
  • Post-birth, the left atrium receives oxygenated blood from the lungs, increasing pressure in this chamber greater than the right atrium, causing fusion of the septum primum and septum secundum, closing the foramen ovale.
  • Annulus ovalis (adults) corresponds to the lower free edge of the septum secundum, while the fossa ovalis represents the septum primum.

 

Right umbilical vein is absent after birth (option C): The right umbilical vein degenerates during fetal life, leaving only the left umbilical vein to carry blood from the placenta. After birth, the left umbilical vein also closes, forming the ligamentum teres (round ligament of the liver).

Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks (option D): The ductus arteriosus functionally closes within 24 to 48 hours due to oxygenation and prostaglandin metabolism. Anatomical closure occurs by 2 to 3 weeks, forming the ligamentum arteriosum.
